lexUnit.name: settle.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to come to terms with one party's demands, or to come to compromise between two parties

sentence.text: ` I intend to change to another firm of solicitors , so naturally I 'll want to settle with you .
` Could you just hold up the bidding while my boys settle with the opposition ? "
You 'll have your turn , but Boisson and I have a score to settle with the bitch first . "

` Now , sir , " Cranston continued quietly as the other traders slunk back , ` I can ask the wardsman to convene a jury of your peers or we can settle on a fine ? "

Within the next few months -- and long before the next election -- they will have to settle these questions or see the spectre of the Winter of Discontent raised to haunt them by gleeful Conservative politicians .
The Sun enters Gemini on the 20th and highlights romance and the good things in life , but tempers could flare if you do n't settle a complex moral or financial issue .
` He was sitting on a committee in Paris to settle the West African problem . "
Stirred by thoughts of heroic deeds against the cruel and monstrous Saracens , Richard chafed , waiting for his father and Philip of France to settle their differences .
He did not settle to this life and had a number of activities , including travel to France and Belgium .
It also gives the new caretaker a chance to settle to his tasks without the added problem of learning switchboard .
She would n't talk to your colleagues , but she 'd settle for talking to me . "

The question was whether to settle for a return to the status quo , or to try to unite the two Koreas and achieve a victory over the communists .
